repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Fixes #30428

For reference, this is how it looks on `master`:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1a6ef24b-cd33-45bd-a41f-1752de0f3c73)

Versus with this PR:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2166a7e1-39a0-44e1-89d3-0dabece59d63)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
local function get_pos_from_offset(offset, contents)
```

p.s.: another case for https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25509 , probably
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -768,34 +768,42 @@ function M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(input, contents)
   return contents
 end
 
+---@param offset integer
+---@param contents string[]
+---@return Range2
+local function get_line_and_col_from_offset(offset, contents)

comment_data.body: would the above comment benefit from a "before => after" example to show what's going on here?
I'm not sure I understand. What exactly would you like me to clarify further?
is this correct? `active_hl` and `get_pos_from_offset` appear to have two numbers (actually not a Range2), not Range4.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -781,34 +781,44 @@ function M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(input, contents)
   return contents
 end
 
+--- Returns the line/column-based position in `contents` at the given offset.
+---
+---@param offset integer
+---@param contents string[]
+---@return Range2
+local function get_pos_from_offset(offset, contents)
+  local i = 0
+  for l, line in ipairs(contents) do
+    if offset >= i and offset < i + #line then
+      return { l - 1, offset - i + 1 }
+    else
+      i = i + #line + 1
+    end
+  end
+end
+
 --- Converts `textDocument/signatureHelp` response to markdown lines.
 ---
 ---@param signature_help lsp.SignatureHelp Response of `textDocument/SignatureHelp`
 ---@param ft string|nil filetype that will be use as the `lang` for the label markdown code block
 ---@param triggers table|nil list of trigger characters from the lsp server. used to better determine parameter offsets
 ---@return string[]|nil table list of lines of converted markdown.
----@return number[]|nil table of active hl
+---@return Range4|nil table of active hl

comment_data.body:
It is correct. Notice how `active_hl` is extended twice with 2 `Range2`s here:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/6e01e0f7b60f5afe802c6feb52b7f7d5fb15cde7/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/util.lua#L908-L912
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -781,34 +781,44 @@ function M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(input, contents)
   return contents
 end
 
+--- Returns the line/column-based position in `contents` at the given offset.

+  local i = 0
+  for l, line in ipairs(contents) do
+    if offset >= i and offset < i + #line then
+      return { l - 1, offset - i + 1 }
+    else
+      i = i + #line + 1
+    end
+  end
+end
+

 ---@return string[]|nil table list of lines of converted markdown.
----@return number[]|nil table of active hl
+---@return Range4|nil table of active hl

comment_data.body: I see, now I get how it contains four elements. It looked like `active_hl` is `Range4[]` at a glance, my bad. Though I believe making it explicit (e.g. `row_start, col_start`, `row_end, `col_end`) would make the code a bit easier to read.

comment_data.body:
Coming from https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30460#discussion_r1798438892, this seems to be fixed:

```suggestion
---@return {[1]: integer, [2]: integer} row, col
```
because Range2 means (start row, start end), not a position. (or line => row? I didn't check this carefully)

note: since this is just a local helper function, we can also simply return two integers rather than a table.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -781,34 +781,44 @@ function M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(input, contents)
   return contents
 end
 
+--- Returns the line/column-based position in `contents` at the given offset.
+---
+---@param offset integer
+---@param contents string[]
+---@return Range2

comment_data.body:
I agree that it would make the code easier to read when not inside an editor, but what you described is exactly the definition of `Range4`:
```lua
---@class Range4
---@inlinedoc
---@field [1] integer start row
---@field [2] integer start column
---@field [3] integer end row
---@field [4] integer end column
```

I prefer to use the existing type here, and either way we do want to consolidate the many position/range abstractions we have (see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25509).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -781,34 +781,44 @@ function M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(input, contents)
   return contents
 end
 
+--- Returns the line/column-based position in `contents` at the given offset.
+---
+---@param offset integer
+---@param contents string[]
+---@return Range2
+local function get_pos_from_offset(offset, contents)
+  local i = 0
+  for l, line in ipairs(contents) do
+    if offset >= i and offset < i + #line then
+      return { l - 1, offset - i + 1 }
+    else
+      i = i + #line + 1
+    end
+  end
+end
+
 --- Converts `textDocument/signatureHelp` response to markdown lines.
 ---
 ---@param signature_help lsp.SignatureHelp Response of `textDocument/SignatureHelp`
 ---@param ft string|nil filetype that will be use as the `lang` for the label markdown code block
 ---@param triggers table|nil list of trigger characters from the lsp server. used to better determine parameter offsets
 ---@return string[]|nil table list of lines of converted markdown.
----@return number[]|nil table of active hl
+---@return Range4|nil table of active hl

comment_data.body: I'll keep the table so that I can still just use `list_extend` without introducing extra variables at the call sites.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -781,34 +781,44 @@ function M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(input, contents)
   return contents
 end
 
+--- Returns the line/column-based position in `contents` at the given offset.
+---
+---@param offset integer
+---@param contents string[]
+---@return Range2

comment_data.body: Yes, I agree. Just wanted to be clear, I meant using local variables while constructing a table (rather than using list_extend which is not type friendly).

comment_data.body:
nit/non-blocker: do we usually prefix our namespaces with `nvim_` ? 

also wondering if we should use dot "." as the separator for namesapces, e.g. `nvim.lsp.foo`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -462,6 +462,8 @@ M[ms.textDocument_typeDefinition] = location_handler
 --- @see # https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-current/#textDocument_implementation
 M[ms.textDocument_implementation] = location_handler
 
+local sig_help_ns = api.nvim_create_namespace('lsp_signature_help')

comment_data.body:
I don't think we have a convention regarding namespace names. E.g. we use [`'vim/snippet'`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/36890824c7edb7bc5458062c14efbfa0b1d280b5/runtime/lua/vim/snippet.lua#L3) in `vim.snippet`, [`'ts.dev'`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/36890824c7edb7bc5458062c14efbfa0b1d280b5/runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/dev.lua#L138) in the TS inspector, etc.

We do seem to prefix these with `vim_` in the LSP namespaces though, so I'll stick to that.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -462,6 +462,8 @@ M[ms.textDocument_typeDefinition] = location_handler
 --- @see # https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-current/#textDocument_implementation
 M[ms.textDocument_implementation] = location_handler
 
+local sig_help_ns = api.nvim_create_namespace('lsp_signature_help')

comment_data.body:
nit:
```suggestion
  local active_offset ---@type [integer, integer]|nil
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -781,34 +781,44 @@ function M.convert_input_to_markdown_lines(input, contents)
   return contents
 end
 
+--- Returns the line/column-based position in `contents` at the given offset.
+---
+---@param offset integer
+---@param contents string[]
+---@return { [1]: integer, [2]: integer }
+local function get_pos_from_offset(offset, contents)
+  local i = 0
+  for l, line in ipairs(contents) do
+    if offset >= i and offset < i + #line then
+      return { l - 1, offset - i + 1 }
+    else
+      i = i + #line + 1
+    end
+  end
+end
+
 --- Converts `textDocument/signatureHelp` response to markdown lines.
 ---
 ---@param signature_help lsp.SignatureHelp Response of `textDocument/SignatureHelp`
 ---@param ft string|nil filetype that will be use as the `lang` for the label markdown code block
 ---@param triggers table|nil list of trigger characters from the lsp server. used to better determine parameter offsets
 ---@return string[]|nil table list of lines of converted markdown.
----@return number[]|nil table of active hl
+---@return Range4|nil table of active hl
 ---@see https://microsoft.github.io/language-server-protocol/specifications/specification-current/#textDocument_signatureHelp
 function M.convert_signature_help_to_markdown_lines(signature_help, ft, triggers)
-  if not signature_help.signatures then
-    return
-  end
   --The active signature. If omitted or the value lies outside the range of
   --`signatures` the value defaults to zero or is ignored if `signatures.length == 0`.
   --Whenever possible implementors should make an active decision about
   --the active signature and shouldn't rely on a default value.
   local contents = {}
-  local active_hl
+  local active_offset ---@type [number, number]|nil

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    it('highlights active parameters in multiline signature labels', function()
```

If I understood correctly, this refers to the second parameter (`activeParameter = 1` with zero-based index) => `_: void`; in line 3 (Row 2, with zero-based index). I was confused why it's not `{ 2, 4, 2, 11 }` -- Could you please clarify which index is exactly being used and document it if it would make it easier to understand?

It looks like we're using 1-based index here for line (row) or 0-based index for column (with end-exclusive), but `vim.highlight.range` seems to accept 0-based index for line/col (Range4 also implies 0-based row/col).
Hmm, maybe I got it; looks like it's because of the additional line introduced as the code is wrapped with a codeblock: \```...```. So it *is* correctly 0-index (so returns `get_pos_from_offset`).

comment_data.diff_hunk:

+      return { l - 1, offset - i + 1 }
+    else
+      i = i + #line + 1
+    end
+  end
+end
+
 --- Converts `textDocument/signatureHelp` response to markdown lines.
 ---
 ---@param signature_help lsp.SignatureHelp Response of `textDocument/SignatureHelp`
 ---@param ft string|nil filetype that will be use as the `lang` for the label markdown code block
 ---@param triggers table|nil list of trigger characters from the lsp server. used to better determine parameter offsets
 ---@return string[]|nil table list of lines of converted markdown.
----@return number[]|nil table of active hl

comment_data.body: And thank you for the review @wookayin <3!

comment_regular_data.body: Would it be possible to add a test case for this?

@justinmk @mfussenegger I think this is ready to go :)
lmk if I'm missing something.

Backport failed for `release-0.10`, because it was unable to cherry-pick the commit(s).

Please cherry-pick the changes locally and resolve any conflicts.
```bash
git fetch origin release-0.10
git worktree add -d .worktree/backport-30460-to-release-0.10 origin/release-0.10
cd .worktree/backport-30460-to-release-0.10
git switch --create backport-30460-to-release-0.10
git cherry-pick -x e0a5c3bb581752569df4490b48cb54e7c1ab0613
```

repo.name: neovim

title: fix(lsp): handle multiline signature help labels
